tidygeocoder 0.3.0.0

Introduction to tidygeocoder

Source: vignettes/tidygeocoder.Rmd
tidygeocoder.Rmd

Geocoding services are used to provide data about addresses such as longitude and latitude coordinates. The goal of tidygeocoder is to make getting data from these services easy. The two main functions to use are geocode() which takes a dataframe as an input and geo() which takes character values or vectors of character values.

Before you jump into using tidygeocoder, you’ll need to make a couple of decisions:

  1. Which geocoding service do you want to use? Specify with the method argument:
  • 'census' : the US Census geocoder service. Covers street level addresses for the US.
  • 'geocodio' : a commercial geocoder service for the US and Canada.
  • 'osm' : the Nominatim service queries OSM (Open Street Map) data.
  • 'iq' : a commercial offering of the Nominatim (OSM) service
  • 'cascade': this method first calls one geocoder service and if no results are found calls another geocoder service.
  1. Do you want to use single-line addressees or address components? (ie. address = '60 Main St, Pawnee, IN' compared to street = '60 Main St', city = 'Pawnee', state = 'IN')
  • For single-line addresses, use the address argument
  • Alternatively, you can use some combination of the street, city, state, county, postalcode, and country arguments. Note that not all of these parameters are required and geocoder services don’t necessarily support all of these inputs, refer to the API documentation of the geocoder services for details. For example, the Census geocoder is only for the United States and has no reason to support a country input.

Making a Query

library(tibble)
library(dplyr)
library(tidygeocoder)

address_single <- tibble(singlelineaddress = c('11 Wall St, NY, NY', '600 Peachtree Street NE, Atlanta, Georgia'))
address_components <- tribble(
  ~str                          , ~cty,             ~st,
  '11 Wall St',                  'NY',               'NY',
  '600 Peachtree Street NE',     'Atlanta',          'GA'
)

The geocode() function takes a dataframe input with address data. Note that all parameters are passed to the geo() function so refer to that function’s documentation for more details on possible arguments.

Use the address argument for single line addresses:

address_single %>% geocode(address = singlelineaddress, method = 'census')
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>   singlelineaddress                           lat  long
#>   <chr>                                     <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 11 Wall St, NY, NY                         40.7 -74.0
#> 2 600 Peachtree Street NE, Atlanta, Georgia  33.8 -84.4

Alternatively use any combination of the following arguments to specify addresses: street, city, state, county, postalcode, and country.

address_components %>% geocode(street = str, city = cty, state = st, method = 'census')
#> # A tibble: 2 x 5
#>   str                     cty     st      lat  long
#>   <chr>                   <chr>   <chr> <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 11 Wall St              NY      NY     40.7 -74.0
#> 2 600 Peachtree Street NE Atlanta GA     33.8 -84.4

To return data other than latitude and longitude, specify full_results = TRUE. Additionally, for the census geocoder you can get details on geographies such as census tracts by specifying return_type = 'geographies'.

census_full1 <- address_single %>% geocode(address = singlelineaddress,
      method = 'census', full_results = TRUE, return_type = 'geographies')
glimpse(census_full1)
#> Rows: 2
#> Columns: 14
#> $ singlelineaddress <chr> "11 Wall St, NY, NY", "600 Peachtree Street NE, Atl…
#> $ lat               <dbl> 40.70747, 33.77085
#> $ long              <dbl> -74.01122, -84.38505
#> $ id                <int> 1, 2
#> $ input_address     <chr> "11 Wall St, NY, NY, , , ", "600 Peachtree Street N…
#> $ match_indicator   <chr> "Match", "Match"
#> $ match_type        <chr> "Exact", "Non_Exact"
#> $ matched_address   <chr> "11 WALL ST, NEW YORK, NY, 10005", "600 PEACHTREE S…
#> $ tiger_line_id     <int> 59659656, 17343689
#> $ tiger_side        <chr> "R", "L"
#> $ state_fips        <int> 36, 13
#> $ county_fips       <int> 61, 121
#> $ census_tract      <int> 700, 1900
#> $ census_block      <int> 1008, 2003

The cascade method

The cascade method by default first tries to use the census geocoder and then if no results are found then it attempts to use the OSM (Nominatim) geocoder. However, you can specify any two methods you would like to try in the order you’d like to try them using the cascade_order argument.

addr_comp1 <- address_components %>%
  bind_rows(tibble(cty=c('Toronto', 'Tokyo'), country = c('Canada', 'Japan')))

addr_comp1 %>% geocode(street = str, state = st, city = cty, country = country, method = 'cascade', verbose = TRUE)
#> Number of Unique Addresses: 4
#> Calling the census batch geocoder
#> Number of Unique Addresses Passed to the Census Batch Geocoder: 4
#> Querying API URL: https://geocoding.geo.census.gov/geocoder/locations/addressbatch
#> Passing the following parameters to the API:
#> format = json
#> benchmark = Public_AR_Current
#> vintage = Current_Current
#> 
#> Number of Unique Addresses: 2
#> Executing single address geocoding...
#> Number of Unique Addresses: 1
#> Querying API URL: http://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search
#> Passing the following parameters to the API:
#> limit = 1
#> street = NA
#> city = Toronto
#> state = NA
#> country = Canada
#> format = json
#> 
#> Query completed in: 0.6 seconds
#> Total query time (including sleep): 1 seconds
#> Number of Unique Addresses: 1
#> Querying API URL: http://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search
#> Passing the following parameters to the API:
#> limit = 1
#> street = NA
#> city = Tokyo
#> state = NA
#> country = Japan
#> format = json
#> 
#> Query completed in: 0.3 seconds
#> Total query time (including sleep): 1 seconds
#> # A tibble: 4 x 7
#>   str                     cty     st    country   lat  long geo_method
#>   <chr>                   <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>     
#> 1 11 Wall St              NY      NY    <NA>     40.7 -74.0 census    
#> 2 600 Peachtree Street NE Atlanta GA    <NA>     33.8 -84.4 census    
#> 3 <NA>                    Toronto <NA>  Canada   43.6 -79.4 osm       
#> 4 <NA>                    Tokyo   <NA>  Japan    35.7 139.  osm

The geo function

As an alternative to using the geocode() function, which operates on dataframes, you can pass address values directly to the geo() function as character values.

salz <- geo('Salzburg, Austria', method = 'osm', full_results = T, verbose = T)
#> Number of Unique Addresses: 1
#> Querying API URL: http://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search
#> Passing the following parameters to the API:
#> limit = 1
#> q = Salzburg, Austria
#> format = json
#> 
#> Query completed in: 0.3 seconds
#> Total query time (including sleep): 1 seconds
glimpse(salz)
#> Rows: 1
#> Columns: 13
#> $ address      <chr> "Salzburg, Austria"
#> $ lat          <dbl> 47.79813
#> $ long         <dbl> 13.04648
#> $ place_id     <int> 206608
#> $ licence      <chr> "Data © OpenStreetMap contributors, ODbL 1.0. https://os…
#> $ osm_type     <chr> "node"
#> $ osm_id       <int> 34964314
#> $ boundingbox  <list> [<"47.6381346", "47.9581346", "12.8864806", "13.2064806…
#> $ display_name <chr> "Salzburg, 5020, Österreich"
#> $ class        <chr> "place"
#> $ type         <chr> "city"
#> $ importance   <dbl> 0.6854709
#> $ icon         <chr> "https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/images/mapicons/poi…

Here is how you would geocode an address using the Census geocoder:

geo(address = "600 Peachtree Street NE, Atlanta, Georgia", method = "census")
#> # A tibble: 1 x 3
#>   address                                     lat  long
#>   <chr>                                     <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 600 Peachtree Street NE, Atlanta, Georgia  33.8 -84.4

Alternatively, you can specify an address in components:

geo(street = "600 Peachtree Street NE", city = "Atlanta", state = "Georgia", method = "census")
#> # A tibble: 1 x 5
#>   street                  city    state     lat  long
#>   <chr>                   <chr>   <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 600 Peachtree Street NE Atlanta Georgia  33.8 -84.4

To use a different geocoder service, you can specify it with the method argument. To geocode multiple addresses, pass them as a vector. In this case we are using the Nominatim (OSM) geocoder service.

geo(address = c("Tokyo, Japan", "Lima, Peru", "Nairobi, Kenya"), method = 'osm')
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#>   address           lat  long
#>   <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
#> 1 Tokyo, Japan    35.7  140. 
#> 2 Lima, Peru     -12.1  -77.0
#> 3 Nairobi, Kenya  -1.28  36.8
